metadata.titleEn: Orthophoto and DSM products obtained from UAV aerial survey for the typical talus landform in the Zheduoshan Mountain, China (2020)
metadata.description: The rock stones in the Zuoduoshan Mountain are heavily weathered and piles of inverted talus are scattered throughout. This dataset is a composite product of visible light photographs for the typical talus in Zuoduoshan Mountain collected by aerial survey from an unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) on 25th – 26th, August 2020. The dataset contains one visible orthophoto and one digital surface model (DSM). The geographic location of the survey area is 101°48'32.58" - 101°52'36.84" E, 30°02'51.03" - 30°06 '32.74" N, with a survey area of 22.6 square kilometres. This survey mission was carried out with the FeiMa UAV D200s equipped with the SONY ILCE-6000 visible camera, using ground-based single base station post processed kinematic (PPK) technology to acquire the spatial position (pos) and related parameters corresponding to each image capturing moment. The images are processed by FeiMa UAV Manager and Pix4d aerial survey software to synthesize the orthophoto of the survey area and generate a high precision DSM at the same time, with a spatial resolution of 10 cm. This product can be used as basic information for research related to the talus in this region, and are also worthy to provide a reliable verification reference for the products obtained from satellite remote sensing technology.
metadata.instructions:
Files: The dataset were compressed using 500 MB split-volume compression of the original files, yielding a total of 12 compressed files (*.rar), including 4 DSM (UAV_DSM.part01.rar - UAV_DSM.part04.rar) and 8 orthophoto data (UAV_Orth.part01.rar - UAV_ Orth.part08.rar).
Usage: Put the downloaded complete package into a same file place and unzip it to get the original files UAV_DSM.tif and UAV_Orth.tif. UAV_DSM.tif, the surface elevation model (DSM) data of the survey area; UAV_Orth.tif, the orthophoto data of the survey area; both have a spatial resolution of 10 cm and are in GeoTIFF format. These two products can be opened and viewed by ArcGIS, ArcGIS Pro, QGIS, ENVI and other software and processed accordingly. The data are with WGS1984 geographic coordinates, and can be set the projection coordinates with different projection methods.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the specific attributes and resolution specifications of a digital surface model used in mapping rockfall landforms in mountainous regions?
Feature Specification.Answer: 10 cm spatial resolution, high-precision elevation data

Quantification.Question: What is the spatial resolution of the imagery obtained through the data collection method in the region?

Interpretation.Question: How do the data collection methods using UAVs and PPK positioning technologies influence the accuracy and reliability of geospatial datasets in rugged mountain areas with severe rock weathering?
Interpretation.Answer: The use of UAVs like the Feima D200s equipped with a visible light camera, coupled with PPK positioning technology, allows for precise acquisition of spatial positions and attitude parameters at the time of image capture. This enhances the accuracy and reliability of geospatial datasets in rugged mountain areas, ensuring high-resolution outputs such as a 10cm spatial resolution orthophoto and digital surface model (DSM), even in challenging environments with severe rock weathering like the Zheduo Mountain region.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential impacts on data accuracy and reliability when using UAV-based photogrammetry with PPK positioning in mountainous regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using UAV-based photogrammetry with PPK positioning in mountainous regions provides high spatial resolution imagery and accurate geolocation data. This combination enhances data accuracy and reliability by precisely determining the spatial position and attitude parameters of each image captured during the survey. Consequently, it results in high-resolution orthophotos and digital surface models, which are crucial for detailed geomorphological studies and can serve as reliable reference data for validating satellite remote sensing products.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the procedural steps involved in using UAV technology to collect and process data for mapping typical rockfall landforms in mountainous regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The data collection process involves using a UAV, specifically a 飞马D200s equipped with a SONY ILCE-6000 visible light camera. The UAV collects imagery over the target area using a single ground-based PPK positioning system to determine the spatial position and attitude parameters for each image. The images are then processed using the 飞马无人机管家 and Pix4d software to create an orthophoto and a high-resolution digital surface model (DSM) with a spatial resolution of 10cm, covering an area of 22.6 square kilometers.

Enablement.Question: What technological innovations and methods enable the creation of high-resolution orthophoto and digital surface model datasets in regions with extensive rock weathering and stone pile landscapes?
Enablement.Answer: The use of drones like the Feima D200s equipped with a SONY ILCE-6000 visible light camera and ground-based single-station PPK positioning technology enables the capture of high-resolution spatial and positional data. Processing software such as Pix4d is then used to synthesize orthophotos and generate high-precision DSMs, allowing for detailed mapping and analysis of regions with complex geological features.
